case_name: Heirs at law of Pyare Mohan Bannerji v. Uttarpara Hitakari Sabha

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated January 4, 1955 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 36 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 4, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 36 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 18, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-

facts.text: Pyare Mohan Bannerji died in October 1874 leaving considerable property.

anchor.surface_text: Pyare Mohan Bannerji died in October 1874 leaving behind him considerable property.

facts.text: Pyare Mohan Bannerji executed a will dated February 12, 1874.

anchor.surface_text: He executed a will dated February 12, 1874, making various bequests, including the payment of certain amounts to the first respondent, Uttar-para Hitakari Sabha.

facts.text: Will made bequests including payment to Uttar-para Hitakari Sabha.

anchor.surface_text: making various bequests, including the payment of certain amounts to the first respondent, Uttar-para Hitakari Sabha.

facts.text: Testator's widow held the property for life until her death on March 25, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, his widow held the property for life till her death on March 25, 1945.

facts.text: After widow's death, property went into possession of appellants, heirs at law of testator.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the property went into the possession of the appellants, who are the heirs at law of the testator.

facts.text: On March 17, 1950, first respondent Uttarpara Hitakari Sabha filed application in Allahabad High Court under s.10 of Official Trustees Act (Act II of 1913), registered as Testamentary Case No. 9 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1950, the first respondent, Uttarpara Hitakari Sabha hereinafter referred to as the Sabha filed an application in the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad under s. 10 of the Official Trustees Act  Act II of 1913  claiming that the late Pyare Mohan Bannerji had created a trust by his will and praying that an official trustee be appointed to be the trustee of the properties of the trust. This was registered as Testamentary Case No. 9 of 1950.

facts.text: Sabha claimed that Pyare Mohan Bannerji created a trust by his will.

anchor.surface_text: claiming that the late Pyare Mohan Bannerji had created a trust by his will and praying that an official trustee be appointed

facts.text: Appellants contested Sabha's claim, contended no trust created, entitled as legal heirs to entire property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contested the claim of the Sabha and contended, inter alia, that no trust had been created by the testator and that the appellants, being the legal heirs of the testator, were entitled to succeed to the entire property left by him.

facts.text: Mootham, J. held that will created trust in favour of Sabha, appointed Official Trustee for all properties in Schedule B.

anchor.surface_text: Mootham, J., as he then was, who heard the said case at the first instance, held that by his last will Pyare Mohan Bannerji created a trust in favour of the Sabha, and appointed the Official Trustee a trustee of all the properties left by Pyare Mohan Bannerji specified in Schedule B to the petition.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court (Malik C.J., Agarwala J.) agreed trust created but Sabha entitled only to half share, appointed Official Trustee for that share.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, a division bench of the said High Court, consisting of Malik, C. J., and Agarwala, J., agreed with Mootham, J., that the will created a trust in favour of the Sabha but the learned Judges held that the Sabha was entitled only to a half share in the cash and properties pertaining to the estate of the said testator, and appointed the Official Trustee as trustee only in regard to the said share

facts.text: First respondent accepted the Division Bench decision.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent accepted that position,

facts.text: Appellants preferred present appeal against High Court judgment insofar as against them.

anchor.surface_text: but the appellants, i.e., the persons claiming to be the heirs at law, preferred the present appeal against the judgment of the High Court in so far as it went against them.

facts.text: Appellants contend under will no trust but only charge created in favour of first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants contends that under the will no a trust but only a charge was created in favour of the first respondent and, therefore, the first respondent could no invoke in aid the provisions of S. 10 of the Act.

facts.text: It is common case that if will created trust, it does not fall under exceptions in s.10.

anchor.surface_text: It is common case that if the will created a trust, it would no fall under any one of the exceptions mentioned in the section.

facts.text: All relatives for whom provision made in will have passed away.

anchor.surface_text: At present it is common case that all the relatives for whom provision was made in the will passed away,

facts.text: No daughters of testator's nephew.

anchor.surface_text: that there are no daughters of testators nephew

facts.text: Sabha is the only institution entitled to receive amounts under the will.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Sabha is the only institution entitled to receive the amounts provided for under the will.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that legal heirs took property subject to a trust rather than a charge.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances visualized at the time the last contingency happened, the fluctuating amount the donees had to pay, the permanent nature of the charity and the declared intention of the testator to pay as much as half the net income towards the carrying out of the said charitable object, we hold that the legal heirs took the property of the testator subject to a trust rather than a charge.

facts.text: High Court conclusion is correct.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct.

facts.text: Testator had wife and nephew Sital Prasad Chatterji at time of will, no children.

anchor.surface_text: At the time the testator executed the will he had a wife, and a nephew by name Sital Prasad Chatterji, but no children.

facts.text: Testator was charitably disposed.

anchor.surface_text: He was also charitably disposed.

facts.text: On last contingency (neither testator nor nephew had issue), property to legal heirs subject to annuities and charges, half net income to Sabha.

anchor.surface_text: The last contingency contemplated was that neither the testator no his nephew had any issue in that event the whole of the property was given to his legal heirs subject to the payment of annuities and charges. ... On the happening of the last contingency, that is, both the testator and his nephew dying without children, his legal heirs took the property subject to the payment of half of the net income to the said Sabha
under s. 10 of the Official Trustees Act  Act II of 1913  claiming that the late Pyare Mohan Bannerji had created a trust by his will

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10, Official Trustees Act (Act II of 1913)
concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for appointment of Official Trustee for property subject to trust where no other trustee willing or capable

anchor.surface_text: provisions of S. 10 of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Cannot invoke if only charge, not trust

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: went against them. Learned companynsel for the appellants companytends that under the will number a trust but only a charge

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10, Official Trustees Act (Act II of 1913)

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of the Act reads If any property is subject to a trust other than a trust which the Official Trustee is prohibited from accepting under the provisions of this Act, and there is notrustee within the local limits of the ordinary or extraordinary original civil jurisdiction of the High Court willing or capable to act in the trust, the High Court may on application make an order for the appointment of the Official Trustee by that name with his consent to be the trustee of such property.

concepts.interpretation: Applies if will created a trust, does not fall under exceptions

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: inary or extraordinary original civil jurisdiction of the High C

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10, Official Trustees Act (Act II of 1913)

anchor.surface_text: A trust is an obligation annexed to the ownership of property, and arising out of a confidence reposed in and accepted by the owner or declared and accepted by him, for the benefit of another, or of another and the owner.

concepts.unlisted_description: Obligation annexed to ownership of property arising out of confidence reposed in owner for benefit of another

anchor.surface_text: Where property of one person is made security for the payment of money to another, the latter person is said to have a charge on the property.

concepts.unlisted_description: Property made security for payment of money

anchor.surface_text: The boundaries between the two concepts are well demarcated

concepts.interpretation: Courts face difficulty construing documents to place in trust or charge category

anchor.surface_text: Where property is given to a person upon condition that he does a certain act or confers a certain benefit on another person, the condition may constitute a trust if it is directed to be, or must necessarily be, performed and satisfied out of the property, and consequently imposes a fiduciary obligation in respect of the property but it will not be construed as a trust if this is not the case and the condition merely imposes a collateral duty.

concepts.interpretation: From Halsbury's Laws of England; devise upon condition of paying sum or annuity does not create trust but may create charge

holdings.text: the legal heirs took the property of the testator subject to a trust rather than a charge

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances visualized at the time the last contingency happened, the fluctuating amount the donees had to pay, the permanent nature of the charity and the declared intention of the testator to pay as much as half the net income towards the carrying out of the said charitable object, we hold that the legal heirs took the property of the testator subject to a trust rather than a charge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied tests for trust vs charge considering circumstances of last contingency, fluctuating payment amounts, permanent charitable purpose, and testator's intention for perpetual payment of half net income imposing fiduciary obligation on legal heirs.

holdings.text: the legal heirs, as owners of the property, were under a fiduciary obligation to pay the said amount for charitable purposes

anchor.surface_text: the question is whether the legal heirs, as owners of the property, were under a fiduciary obligation to pay the said amount for charitable purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiduciary obligation arises from trust created by will for permanent charity, distinguishing from mere charge enforceable only as debt.

holdings.text: a trust was created in favour of the first respondent or not, on the happening of the last contingency

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, only concerned with the question whether a trust was created in favour of the first respondent or not, on the happening of the last contingency,

holdings.reasoning_summary: On last contingency occurring, property passed to heirs subject to regular payment of half net income to Sabha for specified perpetual charities, impressing fiduciary character.

holdings.text: the conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the conclusion arrived at by the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held will created trust in favour of Sabha entitling it to half share, affirmed after applying construction principles and tests to will provisions.

precedents.cited_proposition: It is not necessary to use the word trust in order to create an express trust; every charge does not create a trust but a charge may create a trust depending on the nature of the charge
